content.description:
This route climbs the biggest dike on the left Couch Potato.

Ken and Marv Porter on the first ascent of the first route at Couch Potatoes.  Photo by Karen Trout, approximately 1988.
content.protection: Originally hand drilled 1/4" bolts were used. The route is good enough to be worth upgrading to modern bolts.
content.location: This is a bit left of the hiker's route in to Sunshine Dome.

climbs.name: Power Lounger
climbs.fa: Ken Trout, Kirk Miller, & Marv Porter, 1988

content.description:
This is the next bolt line left of

Thunder Thigh

(the dike).
content.protection: Bring a small rack for the overlap and then clip bolts.

content.description: Potato Peel is the leftmost route on the left Potato. Modern 70 meter ropes should make it possible to reach the natural anchor at 200 feet. Simil-climbing was required with "old" 50 meter ropes.

Pitch 1 (5.8): climb easy friction to a high first bolt that protects a fun and balancy move. Continue to flakes that provide gear protection, and set up a gear anchor at a grassy ledge.

Pitch 2 (5.10-): veer left and surmount the flake/bulge with a good jug. Clip the first bolt and continue on with steeper, more sustained and edgy friction climbing, following well-spaced bolts along a watermark. The pitch mellows out two thirds of the way up but keeps you attentive with a fair run out.

This might not be a good first 5.10 lead.
content.protection:
Pitch 1: 1 bolt, a light rack to 2‚Äù, and a gear anchor.

Pitch 2: 5 bolts and a 1 bolt/hand-sized gear anchor.

Walk off to the left.
content.location: Find a black streak on the blank slab and boulder hop to the start behind a large boulder. Look for the first bolt around 20 meters up.

content.description:
Some unprotected 5.8 friction guards the first bolt. If that doesn't scare you, neither will the the runout 5.9 mantle up to reach the third bolt. Good rock!

From the belay anchor atop pitch one, a nice 5.10 toprope is possible.
content.protection: A few bolts on the first pitch. There is only one on the second.
